nodes.text: Conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis of public investments is broken because cost and benefit estimates are systematically biased and thus mislead resource allocation

We compiled the largest dataset of estimation accuracy for public investments: 2,062 projects across eight investment types, 104 countries, 1927-2013, measuring cost overrun as actual/estimated cost and benefit overrun as actual/estimated benefit (first-year benefits proxy)

Many data points were difficult to obtain and only documentary-evidenced data were included; 327 projects have both cost and benefit overrun data, so tests were run on full sample and subsample to check robustness

Costs are proxied by construction or capital costs and benefits by first-year benefits because full life-cycle data are usually unavailable; first-year benefits are a reasonable proxy for longer-term benefits in practice
The sample may be conservative: data availability likely overrepresents better-managed projects and underrepresents badly performing projects, and survival or selection bias may remain

Statistical testing shows cost and benefit estimates are highly inaccurate and biased: pooled results reject unbiasedness with overwhelming significance and show fat tails, skewness and high kurtosis for cost overrun

Empirical magnitudes: average cost overruns range from 1.24 for roads to 1.96 for dams (i.e., 24% to 96% higher than estimates) and average benefit overruns show shortfalls (e.g., BRT 0.42, rail 0.66); weighted total average benefit overrun about 0.94

Cost underestimation and benefit overestimation compound rather than offset each other: 80% of investments have cost overrun not compensated by benefit overrun and benefit-cost ratios are overestimated by roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on investment type
Conventional theories that errors cancel out (e.g., the Hiding Hand) are rejected by data with overwhelming significance; errors are systematic biases not random errors

Data collection followed established methodology (Pickrell standard) and excluded contaminated studies and poor-quality data; about 25% of cost and 50% of benefit candidate data were rejected for quality reasons

Robustness checks using a subsample of 327 projects with both cost and benefit data, conventional statistical tests, and Bayesian modeling show consistent results across sample, geography, time, and investment type

Behavioral explanation: root causes of bias are planners and managers' optimism, overconfidence, planning fallacy, and strategic misrepresentation, which lead to underestimated risks like scope changes and geology rather than these factors being primary independent causes

Consequences: biased estimates lead to systematic resource misallocation, including initiating projects with negative net benefits and macroeconomic harms in fragile economies (examples include large dams and Olympic projects)

Four reforms proposed to fix the cost-benefit fallacy: systematic de-biasing using outside-view reference class forecasting, skin-in-the-game for forecasters, independent audits separated from political influence, and adapting CBA to democratic, non-expert decision contexts

Evidence that reforms work: reference class forecasting is already used at scale in some countries and independent evaluations report improved accuracy; litigation and accountability have begun to create incentives for better forecasting
